elements.content: General routes to confined spaces of well-defined chemical composition and complex three-dimensional structure have long been sought by materials chemists. Here, we introduce metal–organic framework (MOF) materials as an ideal scaffold upon which such organized complexity can be built. Employing an orthogonal coordination strategy, we constructed a large-pore MOF material with two different modifiable linkers in well-defined positions relative to each other. The independent and quantitative covalent grafting of two distinct chemical groups onto these differently reactive linkers yielded a uniformly bifunctionalized MOF material. Not only does this methodology offer an efficient route via which the properties of well-defined microporous materials can be fine-tuned, but it also creates a solid-state platform for synthetically accessing constructs that better emulate the well-ordered intricacy of biological structures.
elements.clean_text: General routes to confined spaces of well-defined chemical composition and complex three-dimensional structure have long been sought by materials chemists. Here, we introduce metal-organic framework (MOF) materials as an ideal scaffold upon which such organized complexity can be built. Employing an orthogonal coordination strategy, we constructed a large-pore MOF material with two different modifiable linkers in well-defined positions relative to each other. The independent and quantitative covalent grafting of two distinct chemical groups onto these differently reactive linkers yielded a uniformly bifunctionalized MOF material. Not only does this methodology offer an efficient route via which the properties of well-defined microporous materials can be fine-tuned, but it also creates a solid-state platform for synthetically accessing constructs that better emulate the well-ordered intricacy of biological structures.

elements.content: The uniform, covalent postsynthesis bifunctionalization of a metal−organic framework (MOF) material is reported for the first time. A large-pore MOF material composed of two linkers that have orthogonal coordination chemistry and that bear independently reactive functional groups has been constructed. The subsequent covalent grafting of two different chemical functionalities onto these reactive linkers is both independent and quantitative, yielding uniformly bifunctionalized confined spaces.
elements.clean_text: The uniform, covalent postsynthesis bifunctionalization of a metal-organic framework (MOF) material is reported for the first time. A large-pore MOF material composed of two linkers that have orthogonal coordination chemistry and that bear independently reactive functional groups has been constructed. The subsequent covalent grafting of two different chemical functionalities onto these reactive linkers is both independent and quantitative, yielding uniformly bifunctionalized confined spaces.

elements.content: The precise arrangement of cooperating chemical functionalities within confined space is a powerful design motif in biology. This motif is responsible for the catalytic performances of enzymes, prompting a decades-long search for general methods to incorporate it into catalytic materials. Unfortunately, the organization of complex chemical functionality in three dimensions remains a fundamental challenge. Particularly, it is the defining goal of supramolecular catalysis, a field that seeks to construct catalysts that are (i) confined, (ii) multifunctional, (iii) flexible, and (iv) identical.
elements.clean_text: The precise arrangement of cooperating chemical functionalities within confined space is a powerful design motif in biology. This motif is responsible for the catalytic performances of enzymes, prompting a decades-long search for general methods to incorporate it into catalytic materials. Unfortunately, the organization of complex chemical functionality in three dimensions remains a fundamental challenge. Particularly, it is the defining goal of supramolecular catalysis, a field that seeks to construct catalysts that are (i) confined, (ii) multifunctional, (iii) flexible, and (iv) identical.

elements.content: With pores of small-molecule dimensions and constituted of precisely located components, metal–organic framework (MOF) materials bear many similarities with the discrete, bioinspired supramolecular structures that have been developed over the decades. What sets them apart is that, while there are examples of internally functionalizing discrete assemblies, the process of rationally evolving MOFs postassembly is appreciably more facile. Because of their robust framework structure, MOF pores can be systematically decorated with chemical functionalities that are flexible and capable of supramolecular interaction. The postassembly introduction of multiple such functionalities further increases the chemical and three-dimensional complexity of the cavities, satisfying two of the four desired elements for bioinspired catalysts (vide supra).
elements.clean_text: With pores of small-molecule dimensions and constituted of precisely located components, metal-organic framework (MOF) materials bear many similarities with the discrete, bioinspired supramolecular structures that have been developed over the decades. What sets them apart is that, while there are examples of internally functionalizing discrete assemblies, the process of rationally evolving MOFs postassembly is appreciably more facile. Because of their robust framework structure, MOF pores can be systematically decorated with chemical functionalities that are flexible and capable of supramolecular interaction. The postassembly introduction of multiple such functionalities further increases the chemical and three-dimensional complexity of the cavities, satisfying two of the four desired elements for bioinspired catalysts (vide supra).

elements.content: It is the fourth condition, that of generating uniformly multifunctionalized cavities, that has challenged MOF chemists. Telfer and co-workers, with their unique family of 4-component MOFs, have beautifully illustrated the ability to systematically generate well-defined, multifunctional, confined spaces. A more general route to such materials is to introduce multiple chemical functionalities after MOF assembly. However, current methods of doing so unavoidably yield MOFs with nonidentical pores. Nevertheless, the Cohen and Rosi groups’ methods of functionalizing orthogonally reactive linkers that are nonuniformly dispersed throughout a MOF material (A) do offer insight into a strategy for uniform multifunctionalization. Had the modifiable linkers been regularly positioned, these orthogonal modification strategies would have yielded uniformly multifunctional MOFs (B). Herein, we detail how such an end has been realized via the independent functionalization of a well-defined, mixed-linker MOF.
elements.clean_text: It is the fourth condition, that of generating uniformly multifunctionalized cavities, that has challenged MOF chemists. Telfer and co-workers, with their unique family of 4-component MOFs, have beautifully illustrated the ability to systematically generate well-defined, multifunctional, confined spaces. A more general route to such materials is to introduce multiple chemical functionalities after MOF assembly. However, current methods of doing so unavoidably yield MOFs with nonidentical pores. Nevertheless, the Cohen and Rosi groups' methods of functionalizing orthogonally reactive linkers that are nonuniformly dispersed throughout a MOF material (A) do offer insight into a strategy for uniform multifunctionalization. Had the modifiable linkers been regularly positioned, these orthogonal modification strategies would have yielded uniformly multifunctional MOFs (B). Herein, we detail how such an end has been realized via the independent functionalization of a well-defined, mixed-linker MOF.

elements.content: (A) Functionalization of irregularly dispersed, independently reactive MOF linkers. (B) Functionalization of regularly positioned, independently reactive linkers resulting in a uniformly multifunctional MOF. (C) Independently reactive linkers with orthogonal coordination chemistry. (D) KSU-1 viewed down the c axis. (E) Network unit of KSU-1 and its schematic representation.
elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Functionalization of irregularly dispersed, independently reactive MOF linkers. (B) Functionalization of regularly positioned, independently reactive linkers resulting in a uniformly multifunctional MOF. (C) Independently reactive linkers with orthogonal coordination chemistry. (D) KSU-1 viewed down the c axis. (E) Network unit of KSU-1 and its schematic representation.

elements.content: Previous examples of independent multifunctionalization of MOFs involved linkers that were orthogonally modifiable but had identical coordination chemistry. This resulted in materials in which the locations of these orthogonally reactive moieties were not well-defined (A). Our strategy uses linkers that have independently reactive functional groups, as well as orthogonal coordination chemistries (B). We opted for amines and hydroxyls as our reactive functionalities and carboxylates and pyridyls for the orthogonal coordination (C). In combination with M2+ salts, dicarboxylates can form two-dimensional nets with M2+-paddlewheel secondary building units (SBUs), and these nets can be pillared by the dipyridyl linkers to yield mixed-linker structures with different components in well-defined positions. Although M2+-paddlewheel MOFs typically form square nets, low-temperature nucleation of the frameworks can afford the rarer Kagome-type lattices that have the large channels necessary for postsynthesis functionalization of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Previous examples of independent multifunctionalization of MOFs involved linkers that were orthogonally modifiable but had identical coordination chemistry. This resulted in materials in which the locations of these orthogonally reactive moieties were not well-defined (A). Our strategy uses linkers that have independently reactive functional groups, as well as orthogonal coordination chemistries (B). We opted for amines and hydroxyls as our reactive functionalities and carboxylates and pyridyls for the orthogonal coordination (C). In combination with M2+ salts, dicarboxylates can form two-dimensional nets with M2+-paddlewheel secondary building units (SBUs), and these nets can be pillared by the dipyridyl linkers to yield mixed-linker structures with different components in well-defined positions. Although M2+-paddlewheel MOFs typically form square nets, low-temperature nucleation of the frameworks can afford the rarer Kagome-type lattices that have the large channels necessary for postsynthesis functionalization of MOFs.

elements.content: Gratifyingly, when 2-amino-1,4-benzenediacarboxylic acid (BDC-NH2) and meso-α,β-di­(4-pyridyl)­glycol (DPG) were incubated with Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 60 °C for 2 days and then left at room temperature for another 2 days, a mixed-linker MOF material with a Kagome lattice (KSU-1) was obtained (C,D). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the resulting pale-yellow, blocklike crystals revealed BDC-NH2 linkers connected by Zn-paddlewheel SBUs in the ab plane, forming two-dimensional sheets that are pillared together by DPG linkers along the c axis (D,E). The structure has two channels along the c axis: triangular and hexagonal channels that are 1 and 1.7 nm across, respectively. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis of KSU-1 confirmed the purity of bulk phases of the material (Figure S1), which was further corroborated by 1H NMR spectroscopy (). Integration of the BDC-NH2 and DPG peaks indicated that the linkers were present in a 2:1 ratio, respectively, which is as expected for a mixed-linker, paddlewheel MOF (Figure S2). N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K of CO2-activated KSU-1 (Figure S3) indicated that the material does not retain most of its porosity upon evacuation; however, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S4) confirmed that the material has significant solvent-accessible volume, with KSU-1 losing ∼50% of its weight as DMF upon heating.
elements.clean_text: Gratifyingly, when 2-amino-1,4-benzenediacarboxylic acid (BDC-NH2) and meso-α,β-di(4-pyridyl)glycol (DPG) were incubated with Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 60 °C for 2 days and then left at room temperature for another 2 days, a mixed-linker MOF material with a Kagome lattice (KSU-1) was obtained (C,D). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of the resulting pale-yellow, blocklike crystals revealed BDC-NH2 linkers connected by Zn-paddlewheel SBUs in the ab plane, forming two-dimensional sheets that are pillared together by DPG linkers along the c axis (D,E). The structure has two channels along the c axis: triangular and hexagonal channels that are 1 and 1.7 nm across, respectively. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis of KSU-1 confirmed the purity of bulk phases of the material (Figure S1), which was further corroborated by 1H NMR spectroscopy (). Integration of the BDC-NH2 and DPG peaks indicated that the linkers were present in a 2:1 ratio, respectively, which is as expected for a mixed-linker, paddlewheel MOF (Figure S2). N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K of CO2-activated KSU-1 (Figure S3) indicated that the material does not retain most of its porosity upon evacuation; however, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Figure S4) confirmed that the material has significant solvent-accessible volume, with KSU-1 losing ~50% of its weight as DMF upon heating.

elements.content: (A) Schematic representation of sequential, independent functionalization of KSU-1 with butyric anhydride followed by succinic anhydride. (B) 1H NMR spectra of each material in the functionalization sequence digested in a solution of D2SO4 in DMSO-d 6. KSU-1 mono : new multiplets in the 0.5–2.30 ppm region correspond to the aliphatic butyryl chain protons. KSU-1 bi : the new singlet peak at 2.35 ppm corresponds to the aliphatic succinic acid protons. DMF is responsible for the peaks in the 2.60–2.90 ppm region.
elements.clean_text: 2  (A) Schematic representation of sequential, independent functionalization of KSU-1 with butyric anhydride followed by succinic anhydride. (B) 1H NMR spectra of each material in the functionalization sequence digested in a solution of D2SO4 in DMSO-d 6. KSU-1  mono : new multiplets in the 0.5-2.30 ppm region correspond to the aliphatic butyryl chain protons. KSU-1  bi : the new singlet peak at 2.35 ppm corresponds to the aliphatic succinic acid protons. DMF is responsible for the peaks in the 2.60-2.90 ppm region.

elements.content: Having established the purity and porosity of KSU-1, we proceeded to investigate postsynthesis modification. We hypothesized that the amine group of BDC-NH2 is sufficiently nucleophilic to react with linear aliphatic anhydrides under relatively low concentrations, while the hydroxyl of DPG is not. Butyric anhydride was chosen as the electrophile for the amidation reaction, which was performed following a modified literature procedure. After the MOF material was repeatedly immersed in fresh anhydrous CHCl3 solutions of butyric anhydride for a total of 96 h, with constant agitation, the success of the reaction was evaluated using 1H NMR. The amidation product (KSU-1 mono ) was thoroughly rinsed, evacuated, and then digested in a solution of D2SO4 in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d 6. The 1H NMR spectrum obtained was compared to that of KSU-1 (B). All of the peaks corresponding to the parent BDC-NH2 protons had shifted, and new peaks corresponding to the protons of the butyryl substituent of the amide had appeared in the aliphatic region (0.5–2.5 ppm). The integration ratios were consistent with a DPG/butyryl ratio of 1:2, as expected for quantitative, and selective, functionalization of the amine (Figure S2). High-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) of the MOF material digested in a solution of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane (DABCO) in DMSO revealed masses corresponding to BDC-amide and unreacted DPG only ( and S5). Control experiments showed that the DABCO solution does not hydrolyze any esters present (vide infra), so this result further confirmed that the linear anhydride did not react with DPG.
elements.clean_text: Having established the purity and porosity of KSU-1, we proceeded to investigate postsynthesis modification. We hypothesized that the amine group of BDC-NH2 is sufficiently nucleophilic to react with linear aliphatic anhydrides under relatively low concentrations, while the hydroxyl of DPG is not. Butyric anhydride was chosen as the electrophile for the amidation reaction, which was performed following a modified literature procedure. After the MOF material was repeatedly immersed in fresh anhydrous CHCl3 solutions of butyric anhydride for a total of 96 h, with constant agitation, the success of the reaction was evaluated using 1H NMR. The amidation product (KSU-1  mono ) was thoroughly rinsed, evacuated, and then digested in a solution of D2SO4 in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d 6. The 1H NMR spectrum obtained was compared to that of KSU-1 (B). All of the peaks corresponding to the parent BDC-NH2 protons had shifted, and new peaks corresponding to the protons of the butyryl substituent of the amide had appeared in the aliphatic region (0.5-2.5 ppm). The integration ratios were consistent with a DPG/butyryl ratio of 1:2, as expected for quantitative, and selective, functionalization of the amine (Figure S2). High-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) of the MOF material digested in a solution of 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) in DMSO revealed masses corresponding to BDC-amide and unreacted DPG only ( and S5). Control experiments showed that the DABCO solution does not hydrolyze any esters present (vide infra), so this result further confirmed that the linear anhydride did not react with DPG.

elements.content: Schematic representation of the high-resolution ESI-MS analysis of KSU-1 mono and KSU-1 bi . The BDC derivatives are ionized only in the negative mode, while the DPG derivatives are ionized only in the positive mode. The spectra are available in Figure S5. KSU-1 mono : in the negative mode, the [M – H+] peak corresponds to deprotonated BDC-amide, while the [M + H+] peak corresponds to protonated DPG. KSU-1 bi : in the negative mode, the [M – H+] peak again corresponds to deprotonated BDC-amide, while the [M + H+] peak corresponds to protonated DPG-diester.
elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic representation of the high-resolution ESI-MS analysis of KSU-1  mono  and KSU-1  bi . The BDC derivatives are ionized only in the negative mode, while the DPG derivatives are ionized only in the positive mode. The spectra are available in Figure S5. KSU-1  mono : in the negative mode, the [M - H+] peak corresponds to deprotonated BDC-amide, while the [M + H+] peak corresponds to protonated DPG. KSU-1  bi : in the negative mode, the [M - H+] peak again corresponds to deprotonated BDC-amide, while the [M + H+] peak corresponds to protonated DPG-diester.

elements.content: PXRD (Figure S1) and TGA (Figure S4) of KSU-1 mono indicated that the material preserved its crystallinity and retained significant porosity, with the material losing ∼35% of its weight as DMF. Adsorption isotherms with N2 at 77 K revealed that the porosity of evacuated KSU-1 mono could be accessed partially with CO2 activation (Figure S3). The large solvent-accessible volume that still remained in KSU-1 mono indicated that the second functionalization of the MOF material was feasible. We attempted the nucleophilic ring opening of succinic anhydride by the DPG linker of KSU-1 mono to produce an aliphatic acid attached to DPG via an ester linkage, a reaction previously used for the monofunctionalization of a MOF material. The MOF was immersed in a suspension of succinic anhydride in anhydrous CHCl3 and agitated for 72 h to produce the bifunctionalized material KSU-1 bi . After washing and evacuation, KSU-1 bi was digested in a solution of D2SO4 in DMSO-d 6 for 1H NMR analysis. Because of the acidic NMR solvent mixture, we expected that the labile ester linkage would be hydrolyzed and that the spectrum of KSU-1 bi would be identical with that of KSU-1 mono , except for the presence of aliphatic protons corresponding to the freed succinic acid. The results matched this scenario, with proton peak integration indicating a 1:1 ratio of succinic acid to butyric amide (Figure S3). Because the −NH2 to −OH ratio in the parent material KSU-1 is also 1:1, this final result indicated the quantitative, independent functionalization of the BDC-NH2 and DPG linkers.
elements.clean_text: PXRD (Figure S1) and TGA (Figure S4) of KSU-1  mono  indicated that the material preserved its crystallinity and retained significant porosity, with the material losing ~35% of its weight as DMF. Adsorption isotherms with N2 at 77 K revealed that the porosity of evacuated KSU-1  mono  could be accessed partially with CO2 activation (Figure S3). The large solvent-accessible volume that still remained in KSU-1  mono  indicated that the second functionalization of the MOF material was feasible. We attempted the nucleophilic ring opening of succinic anhydride by the DPG linker of KSU-1  mono  to produce an aliphatic acid attached to DPG via an ester linkage, a reaction previously used for the monofunctionalization of a MOF material. The MOF was immersed in a suspension of succinic anhydride in anhydrous CHCl3 and agitated for 72 h to produce the bifunctionalized material KSU-1  bi . After washing and evacuation, KSU-1  bi  was digested in a solution of D2SO4 in DMSO-d 6 for 1H NMR analysis. Because of the acidic NMR solvent mixture, we expected that the labile ester linkage would be hydrolyzed and that the spectrum of KSU-1  bi  would be identical with that of KSU-1  mono , except for the presence of aliphatic protons corresponding to the freed succinic acid. The results matched this scenario, with proton peak integration indicating a 1:1 ratio of succinic acid to butyric amide (Figure S3). Because the -NH2 to -OH ratio in the parent material KSU-1 is also 1:1, this final result indicated the quantitative, independent functionalization of the BDC-NH2 and DPG linkers.

elements.content: To confirm that the succinic acid was indeed covalently attached to DPG via an ester linkage, KSU-1 bi was disassembled in a solution of DABCO in DMSO-d 6. Two separate signals corresponding to the −CH2 protons of the ester derivative were present in the 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S2), and a mass signal corresponding to the DPG-diester was present in the ESI-MS spectrum ( and S5). Signals corresponding to unreacted DPG and DPG-monoester were not observed, further substantiating quantitative conversion. The PXRD pattern (Figure S1) indicates that the material remained crystalline. Gas adsorption isotherms again revealed partial porosity (Figure S2), as well as the presence of mesopores. These are attributed to the slight dissolution of linkers during the reactions. TGA (Figure S4) indicates that KSU-1 bi still has a large amount of solvent-accessible volume because it loses ∼25% of its weight as DMF.
elements.clean_text: To confirm that the succinic acid was indeed covalently attached to DPG via an ester linkage, KSU-1  bi  was disassembled in a solution of DABCO in DMSO-d 6. Two separate signals corresponding to the -CH2 protons of the ester derivative were present in the 1H NMR spectrum (Figure S2), and a mass signal corresponding to the DPG-diester was present in the ESI-MS spectrum ( and S5). Signals corresponding to unreacted DPG and DPG-monoester were not observed, further substantiating quantitative conversion. The PXRD pattern (Figure S1) indicates that the material remained crystalline. Gas adsorption isotherms again revealed partial porosity (Figure S2), as well as the presence of mesopores. These are attributed to the slight dissolution of linkers during the reactions. TGA (Figure S4) indicates that KSU-1  bi  still has a large amount of solvent-accessible volume because it loses ~25% of its weight as DMF.

elements.content: The 1H NMR and mass spectra support that the butyryl group is attached to BDC-NH2, while the succinic acid is tethered to DPG; thus, we can conclude that these moieties are regularly arranged throughout the material. We should note that the −NH2 group has positional disorder in the crystal. So, while the functionalization is regular in that each unit cell has the same components, their spatial arrangements are not identical.
elements.clean_text: The 1H NMR and mass spectra support that the butyryl group is attached to BDC-NH2, while the succinic acid is tethered to DPG; thus, we can conclude that these moieties are regularly arranged throughout the material. We should note that the -NH2 group has positional disorder in the crystal. So, while the functionalization is regular in that each unit cell has the same components, their spatial arrangements are not identical.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have taken two strategies for increasing the chemical diversity of MOF cavitiespillared mixed-linker MOF assembly and postsynthesis functionalizationand combined them to demonstrate a methodology for uniformly tailoring MOF pores with multiple functionalities. This new tool in the MOF construction arsenal opens exciting opportunities in the development of multifunctional MOFs. While the lack of permanent microporosity will limit this particular material and its multifunctionalized derivatives to solution-phase applications such as catalysis, the methodology we have demonstrated can serve as a blueprint as we seek to construct more robust materials. In this work, we modified the MOF with proof-of-concept moieties. However, one can envision employing this strategy to functionalize MOF cavities to achieve a myriad of cooperative actions in catalysis, detection, sequestration, etc. The uniformity of the strategy will increase the selectivity of these various applications and bring us closer to a long-standing goal of materials chemistry: the construction of highly functionalized, uniform, confined spaces in which the sophisticated functions of biological structures can be emulated.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have taken two strategies for increasing the chemical diversity of MOF cavitiespillared mixed-linker MOF assembly and postsynthesis functionalizationand combined them to demonstrate a methodology for uniformly tailoring MOF pores with multiple functionalities. This new tool in the MOF construction arsenal opens exciting opportunities in the development of multifunctional MOFs. While the lack of permanent microporosity will limit this particular material and its multifunctionalized derivatives to solution-phase applications such as catalysis, the methodology we have demonstrated can serve as a blueprint as we seek to construct more robust materials. In this work, we modified the MOF with proof-of-concept moieties. However, one can envision employing this strategy to functionalize MOF cavities to achieve a myriad of cooperative actions in catalysis, detection, sequestration, etc. The uniformity of the strategy will increase the selectivity of these various applications and bring us closer to a long-standing goal of materials chemistry: the construction of highly functionalized, uniform, confined spaces in which the sophisticated functions of biological structures can be emulated.

metadata.title:
Uniform, Binary Functionalization of a Metal–Organic
Framework Material
